parts: I bought a new car. Can I drive it using the insurance I have for another car in Maryland

In Maryland, you can typically drive a newly purchased car using the insurance from your existing car for a short period, often 30 days, to allow you time to add the new vehicle to your policy. However, it's important to check with your insurance company to confirm their specific requirements and ensure you have the appropriate coverage for your new car.
How do I transfer my l license plates from my old car to a car. I just purchased in Maryland.

To transfer your license plates from your old car to your new car in Maryland, follow these steps:

1. **Remove Plates from Old Car**: Remove the license plates from your old car.

2. **Gather Necessary Documents**: Collect the following documents:
   - Title or proof of ownership of the new car.
   - Proof of insurance for the new car.
   - Maryland Safety Inspection Certificate (if applicable).

3. **Complete the Application for Certificate of Title**: This form (Form VR-005) is available on the Maryland MVA website or at any MVA branch office.

4. **Visit an MVA Branch**: Go to a Maryland MVA branch office with the necessary documents. You may also need to provide proof of identity and residency.

5. **Pay Fees**: Pay the required title transfer and registration fees. The MVA will calculate the exact amount based on the specifics of your vehicle and transaction.

6. **Submit Old Title (if applicable)**: If you are transferring the title from your old car to your new car, you will need to submit the old title.

7. **Receive New Registration**: The MVA will process your request and provide you with a new registration card reflecting the transfer of the license plates to your new car.

8. **Attach Plates to New Car**: Once the transfer is complete, attach the old plates to your new car.

It's a good idea to check the Maryland MVA website or contact them directly for any specific requirements or updates to the process.

### Recall List for the 2012 Kia Forte

Official recalls have been issued for the 2012 Kia Forte by the NHTSA. The complete details of all recalls are listed below, along with what they cover and the recommended solutions. 

Recalls don't cost you anything to get fixed, but most are time-limited, so if your car is affected you should call your local Kia service department immediately! 

If you have questions about a recall, write down your VIN & then call 【163†Kia customer service】.

# 2012-2014 Kia Forte, Forte Koup: Recall Alert

[Image 1: img 1731639230 1465848679086 jpg]  2013 Kia Forte | Manufacturer image

By Cars.com Editors

December 13, 2017

Share 

CARS.COM 

Vehicles Affected: Approximately 134,000 model-year 2012-14 Kia Forte sedans and hatchbacks and Forte Koup coupes

The Problem: The brake pedal stopper pad may deteriorate, allowing the brakelight switch plunger to remain extended when the brake pedal is released, and the brakelights to remain illuminated. Deterioration can also allow the shift lever to be moved without depressing the brake pedal, or to activate the engine management brake pedal override feature.

If the brakelight switch plunger does not retract when the brake pedal is not being pressed, the brakelights may stay illuminated, increasing the risk of a crash. Additionally, if the brake switch plunger is not retracted, the transmission can be shifted out of Park without depressing the brake pedal, also increasing the risk of a crash.

The Fix: Dealers will replace the brake pedal stopper pad for free. 

What Owners Should Do: Kia will begin notifying owners Jan. 30, 2018. Owners can call the automaker at 800-333-4542, the 【8†National Highway Traffic Safety Administration’s†www.nhtsa.gov】 vehicle-safety hotline at 888-327-4236 or visit 【9†www.safercar.gov†www.safercar.gov】 to check their 【10†vehicle identification number†vinrcl.safercar.gov】 and learn more. 

Need to Find a Dealer for Service? Go to Cars.com 【11†Service & Repair】 to find your local dealer. To check for other recalls, and to schedule a free recall repair at your local dealership, click here: 【12†Kia Forte】; 【13†Kia Forte Koup】

【11†More Recalls】

content.title: 2012-2014 Kia Forte, Forte Koup: Recall Alert | Cars.com

parts:
The 2012 Kia Forte EX has had several recalls over the years. Here are some key recalls you should be aware of:

1. **Engine Compartment Fire Risk**: This recall affects a significant number of Kia vehicles, including the 2012 Forte. The issue involves a risk of an engine compartment fire while the car is parked or driving, increasing the risk of injury【13†source】【14†source】.

2. **Brake Pedal Stopper Pad Deterioration**: The brake pedal stopper pad may deteriorate, causing the brake lights to stay on even when the brake pedal is not pressed. This can also allow the shift lever to be moved without depressing the brake pedal, increasing the risk of a crash. Kia dealers will replace the brake pedal stopper pad for free【14†source】.

3. **Engine Damage Leading to Fire**: Another recall involves potential engine damage that could lead to a fire, affecting a large number of vehicles. This recall was announced in December 2020 and involves inspecting and repairing the engine as necessary to prevent this risk【13†source】.

For detailed information and to check if your specific vehicle is affected, you can visit the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) website and enter your Vehicle Identification Number (VIN) to see all applicable recalls. It's also a good idea to contact a Kia dealer to ensure all necessary repairs are completed.
